Edward Allen Hitchcock McDonald (brother) }} '''Marshall McDonald''' (October 18, 1835 – September 1, 1895) was an [[Americans|American]] [[engineer]], [[geologist]], [[mineralogist]], [[Fish farming|pisciculturist]], and [[Fisheries science|fisheries scientist]].{{Harvnb|Blume|2011|p=315.}} McDonald served as the [[commissioner]] of the [[United States Fish Commission|United States Commission of Fish and Fisheries]] from 1888 until his death in 1895. He is best known for his inventions of a number of [[Fish hatchery|fish hatching]] apparatuses and a [[fish ladder]] that enabled [[salmon]] and other migrating [[fish]] species to ascend the [[rapid]]s of [[watercourse]]s resulting in an increased [[Spawn (biology)|spawning]] ground.{{Harvnb|Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle|1896|p=99.}} McDonald's administration of the U.S. Commission of Fish and Fisheries was notably free of scandal and furthered the "protection and culture" of fish species throughout the United States. ==Early life== McDonald was born on October 18, 1835 to [[Angus William McDonald]] and his wife, Leacy Anne Naylor, in [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]], [[Hampshire County, West Virginia|Hampshire County]], [[Virginia]] (now [[West Virginia]]).{{Citation| last=National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution | first= | author-link = Sons of the American Revolution | year=1890| title=Sons of the American Revolution Membership Application: Marshall McDonald | publisher=[[Sons of the American Revolution|National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution]] | location = [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]]| isbn= | url=http://search.ancestry.com/iexec?htx=View&r=an&dbid=2204&iid=32596_242034-00032&fn=Marshall&ln=McDonald&st=r&ssrc=pt_t38718431_p19274915099_kpgz0q3d32799_m1&pid=17646 | accessdate=May 1, 2012}}{{Harvnb|Bruette|1895|p=200.}}{{Harvnb|Benjamin|1897|p=35.}}{{Harvnb|Leslie|1888|p=419.}}{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=218.}} McDonald was the sixth child and fourth son of Angus and Leacy Anne McDonald. He was named for the Marshall family, many members of which were friends of his father. The McDonalds raised their nine children, consisting of five sons and four daughters, in a [[Log cabin|log dwelling]] in Romney owned by Leacy Anne's father, William Naylor.{{Harvnb|Munske|Kerns|2004|p=183.}} The structure, currently known as the Davis History House, remains standing at its original site at the corner of Main and Bolton Streets and serves as a [[museum]] mainted by the Hampshire County Public Library. McDonald's father was a prominent community leader in Romney and served on the [[Board of directors|board of trustees]] of [[Romney Academy]],{{Harvnb|Virginia General Assembly|1839|p=131.}}{{Harvnb|Morrison|1917|p=152.}} an academy that McDonald likely attended as well as its successor institution, the [[Romney Classical Institute]].{{Harvnb|Moore|1895|p=1043.}} Following the death of his mother, McDonald's father sold the Naylor family's log dwelling in 1849 and moved to [[Hannibal, Missouri|Hannibal]], [[Missouri]] in the 1850s only to return to Virginia a few years later upon marrying his second wife, [[Cornelia Peake McDonald|Cornelia Peake]]. McDonald and his family were still residing in Romney at the time of the [[1850 United States Census]].{{Citation| last=[[National Archives and Records Administration]] | first= | author-link = | year=1850| title=1850 United States Federal Census, Year: 1850; Census Place: District 24, Hampshire, Virginia; Roll: M432_948; Page: 176A; Image: 355. | publisher=Ancestry.com. 1850 United States Federal Census [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2009. Images reproduced by FamilySearch. | location = | isbn= | url=http://search.ancestry.com/Browse/view.aspx?dbid=8054&iid=4206370_00355&pid=15109932&email=&o_xid=&o_sch=Sharing&o_lid=| accessdate=May 1, 2012}} It is unknown whether McDonald and his siblings accompanied their father on his move to Missouri. == Education and early academic career == From 1854 to 1855, McDonald studied [[natural history]] under [[Spencer Fullerton Baird]] at the [[Smithsonian Institution]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{Citation | last = | first =| author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Col. Marshall McDonald; Newly Appointed Fish Commissioner. | newspaper = The Meriden Daily Republican | pages = | date = January 28, 1888 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4141AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7RMLAAAAIBAJ&pg=2891,1465405 | accessdate=May 1, 2012}} McDonald entered the third class of the [[Virginia Military Institute]] in [[Lexington, Virginia|Lexington]], Virginia in 1855,{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=219.}} where [[Stonewall Jackson|Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson]] was one of his professors. During the 1858–1859 [[academic year]], McDonald attended the [[University of Virginia]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]]. McDonald resumed his studies at the Virginia Military Institute and graduated from that institution in July 1860.{{Harvnb|Davis|1992|p=323.}} McDonald served as an assistant [[Professors in the United States|professor]] in [[chemistry]] under Jackson at the Virginia Military Institute from Fall 1860 until the outbreak of the [[American Civil War]] in April 1861{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=222.}} and taught intermittently throughout the course of the war.{{Harvnb|Wise|1882|p=19.}}{{Harvnb|Benjamin|1897|p=36.}} ==Military career in the American Civil War== McDonald enlisted in the [[Confederate States Army]] on April 27, 1861 and served initially as a [[Lieutenant]] [[Engineer Officer]] and [[inspector general]] of the staff of his former professor, [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Lieutenant general|Lieutenant General]] Stonewall Jackson. McDonald later served as a [[Staff (military)|staff officer]] for [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Major general|Major General]] [[Martin Luther Smith]] and as an engineer officer for Lieutenant General [[John C. Pemberton]] after being transferred to [[New Orleans]]. [[File:Davis History House Romney WV 2012 04 30 02.JPG|thumb|right|250px|McDonald was raised (and likely born) in this [[Log cabin|log dwelling]] in [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]], [[Virginia]] (now [[West Virginia]]). Known as the Davis History House, McDonald's childhood home serves as an [[American Civil War]] museum maintained by the Hampshire County Public Library.]] While serving as chief engineer under Pemberton, McDonald was taken as a [[prisoner of war]] by the [[Union Army]] at [[Vicksburg, Mississippi|Vicksburg]], [[Mississippi]] in 1863. During the war, McDonald and other former cadets returned to the Virginia Military Institute to instruct pupils while on [[parole]] or recuperating from injuries. In 1864 while McDonald was on parole, one of his students, [[John Sergeant Wise]], recounted of having McDonald as a professor: 'Marshall McDonald hobbles in to point with his [[crutch]] at the problems on the [[Chalkboard|black-board]], until he can once more point with his [[sword]] towards "the looming bastion fringed with fire."' Of the professors at the institute during the war, Wise remarked, "they taught with a zest and freshness as we seldom see." McDonald was further promoted to the rank of [[Major (United States)|Major]] in command of engineers on the staff of [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#General (Full general)|General]] [[Braxton Bragg]] and was to be promoted to the ranks of Colonel and Brigadier General when the war ended. While serving as an officer in an engineer corps, McDonald saw "much active service." McDonald and his four brothers served with distinction in the Confederate States Army, but only three of his brothers survived the war. McDonald's father was one of the first Hampshire County residents to volunteer to fight for the Confederacy in 1861 and was [[Commission (document)|commissioned]] as a Colonel in command of [[Cavalry in the American Civil War|cavalry]]. McDonald's father died in battle in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], Virginia in 1864. == Return to Virginia Military Institute == Following the war in 1865, McDonald returned to the Virginia Military Institute where he was appointed a professor with the rank of Colonel instructing and serving as chair of the subjects of chemistry, [[geology]], [[mineralogy]], and [[metallurgy]].{{Harvnb|Virginia Military Institute|1869|p=13.}} McDonald was appointed by the Board of Directors to replace Colonel Gilham as chair of the subjects of chemistry, mineralogy, and geology, who had in turn been appointed to replace [[George Washington Custis Lee]] the previous year.{{Harvnb|Smith|1890|p=}}{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=227.}} Upon his return to the Virginia Military Institute, McDonald established the institution's first museum. During the 1867–1868 academic year, McDonald's chair was further subdivided as new lecture halls were being completed within [[Barracks, Virginia Military Institute|the restored barracks]] with McDonald retaining the subjects of mineralogy, geology, and metallurgy. McDonald's colleagues among the faculty included Superintendent [[Francis Henney Smith]] and professors [[Matthew Fontaine Maury]], [[Scott Shipp]], [[John Mercer Brooke]], and George Washington Custis Lee. Toward the end of his tenure at the Virginia Military Institute, McDonald occupied the chair of geology and [[mining engineering]]. [[File:Virginia Military Institute wmm.jpg|thumb|250px|left|An illustration of General [[Francis Henney Smith]] addressing the faculty of the [[Virginia Military Institute]], including McDonald, in regard to the institution's restoration following the [[American Civil War]].]] In 1875, McDonald developed an interest in [[fish farming]] and became administrator of the Virginia state fish hatchery at [[Wytheville, Virginia|Wytheville]]. He was appointed as the sole Fish Commissioner of Virginia shortly thereafter. It was during his tenure as the Fish Commissioner of Virginia that McDonald invented the [[fish ladder]] that was named for him. In 1877, McDonald was commissioned by Virginia to conduct a survey of [[mineral resource]]s within the [[James River]] basin, the findings of which he reported to the [[Virginia General Assembly]] in 1879. McDonald continued to instruct at the Virginia Military Institute until 1879, when he was invited by his former professor Spencer Fullerton Baird to a position at the [[United States Fish Commission|United States Commission of Fish and Fisheries]]. McDonald accepted the position with the Fish Commission and submitted his resignation from the Virginia Fish Commission to [[Governor of Virginia]], [[Fitzhugh Lee]]. ==United States Fish Commission== McDonald was appointed to an assistant position within the United States Fish Commission where he was a special agent under Baird and responsible for compiling and publishing fishery statistics related to the [[1880 United States Census]]. Following the census, he then served as superintendent of the [[shad]] hatcheries of the [[Potomac River]]. During his subsequent years at the Fish Commission, McDonald was responsible for the distribution of "young fishes" and of "food-fishes" and later served as Chief of the Division of Fish Culture. In 1885, McDonald was appointed Chief Assistant Commissioner of the Fish Commission. He continued in that capacity until he was appointed by [[United States President]] [[Grover Cleveland]] in January 1888 to replace Dr. [[George Brown Goode]] as the Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries.{{Harvnb|Taylor|2001|p=83.}} Brown had been temporarily filling the position of Fish Commissioner following Baird's death. McDonald took his [[oath of office]] on February 18, 1888. His appointment was widely recognized as an "excellent" choice due to the breadth of his experience, organizational and leadership abilities, and sense of duty and responsibility to the American people. McDonald was also viewed as one of the "most accomplished" fish culturists in the United States at the time of his appointment. As Fish Commissioner, McDonald was initially paid [[United States dollar|$]]5,000 per annum and had at his disposal three [[yacht]]s and 22 fishing stations to conduct research and carry out the commission's efforts. [[File:Medals Bestowed Upon Marshall McDonald for His Inventions in Pisiculture.jpg|thumb|right|250px|McDonald was awarded medals ''(pictured)'' from international fishery exhibitions at [[Berlin]] and [[London]] and from the Société d’Acclimation in [[Paris]] for his inventions and improvements in the field of fish farming.]] As Fish Commissioner, one of McDonald's most important works was his plan to undertake a biological and physical survey of American fisheries and fish culture more thorough than any previously undertaken.{{Harvnb|Moore|1895|p=1042.}} McDonald believed the first step toward building "a comprehensive knowledge of the conditions of greatest productiveness" of American fisheries was to understand the primary food supply of fish, which McDonald termed "aquatic pastorage." McDonald also initiated controversial changes in the Fish Commission imposing a bureaucratic structure inspired by his previous military career and solidifying the commission's emphasis on fish culture. In 1893, McDonald warned [[Oregon]] [[Governor of Oregon|governor]] [[Sylvester Pennoyer]] of "the disastrous outlook for the future of the salmon fisheries of the [[Columbia River|Columbia]]."{{Harvnb|Taylor|2001|p=3.}} ===Fish hatching innovations=== Throughout his tenure at the Fish Commission, McDonald invented and designed a number of innovative [[fish hatchery|fish hatching]] apparatuses and appliances.{{Harvnb|Bowers|1902|p=317.}} McDonald's most prominent apparatus was a [[fish ladder]] that enabled salmon and other migrating fish species to ascend the rapids of watercourses, thus increasing the extent of their spawning grounds.{{Citation | last = | first =| author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Death of Marshall McDonald; The United States Fish Commissioner Dies After Long Suffering from Pulmonary Disease. | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | pages = | date = September 2, 1895 | url = http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40915FE3A5E10738DDDAB0894D1405B8585F0D3 | accessdate=May 1, 2012}} In 1871, McDonald devised "automatic hatching jars" which revolutionized the field of fish farming and were widely utilized by the United States Fish Commission, several state commissions, and commissions in [[Europe]] and [[Japan]]. The hatching jar apparatus enabled the "vast extension" of the propagation of [[shad]] accomplished in the 1880s and 1890s and rendered the work of the Fish Commission practicable commercially. In 1880, he designed a [[cod]] box that produced the tidal motion necessary for the hatching of floating [[Egg (biology)#Fish eggs|eggs]]. McDonald further perfected his design of the cod box in 1888. In the winter of 1883, McDonald developed a tidal apparatus for the hatching of floating [[halibut]] eggs and those of other marine species. The vast production and distribution of fish eggs by the Fish Commission was possible through the utilization of this tidal apparatus. Through the usage of this apparatus, the process of hatching eggs was made cheaper and increased the fish farming output capacity of the commission. ===Awards and honors=== Prior to his appointment as Fish Commissioner, McDonald was awarded [[gold medal]]s and [[diploma]]s from international fishery exhibitions at [[Berlin]] and [[London]] and a [[silver medal]] from the Société d’Acclimation in [[Paris]] for his inventions and improvements in the field of fish farming. In addition, he received a "special medal" from the Société d’Acclimation for a fish ladder he devised for the [[Vienne (river)|River Vienne]] in southwestern [[France]]. ==Later life and death== [[File:1514 R Street NW Washington DC 2012 04 21 02.JPG|thumb|right|McDonald's row house at 1514 R Street, [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|Northwest]] in the [[Logan Circle, Washington, D.C.|Logan Circle]] neighborhood of [[Washington, D.C.]] where he resided until his death in 1895.]] At the time of his application submission to the Sons of the American Revolution in 1890, McDonald was residing at 1514 R Street, [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|Northwest]] in what is now known as the [[Logan Circle, Washington, D.C.|Logan Circle]] [[Neighbourhood|neighborhood]] of [[Washington, D.C.]] After suffering from [[tuberculosis]] for several months, McDonald traveled to the [[Adirondack Mountains]] with his wife in the early summer of 1895 seeking to benefit from the region's "health-giving air." McDonald's condition began to deteriorate and he returned to his residence in Washington, D.C. where he died the following week on Sunday morning, September 1, 1895. McDonald was interred on September 3 next to his daughter Nannie in Lot 432 East at [[Oak Hill Cemetery (Washington, D.C.)|Oak Hill Cemetery]] in Washington's [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] neighborhood.{{cite web |url=http://www.oakhillcemeterydc.org/Burials/432e.pdf |title=Oak Hill Cemetery: Burials in Lot 432 East |work= |publisher=[[Oak Hill Cemetery (Washington, D.C.)|Oak Hill Cemetery]] |location=[[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]], [[Washington, D.C.]] |accessdate=May 1, 2012}} McDonald was a member of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Protestant Episcopal Church]] and served as a [[vestryman]] at [[Lee Chapel]], which he was partly instrumental in building.{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=235.}} == Legacy == In his ''[[Forest and Stream]]'' [[magazine]] following McDonald's death in 1895, [[Charles Hallock]] recounted "the record of [McDonald's] administration is an honorable one. By the death of Commissioner McDonald the country loses a public officer who has served faithfully honestly and well." "The closing of his life is a loss to fish culture and to the public interests." [[Marcus Benjamin]], in his remembrance of McDonald for the District of Columbia Sons of the American Revolution, remarked: "His articles and reports on the fishing industries of the world are of great interest and his efforts in behalf of the [[oyster]] have resulted in much good." Benjamin further stated, "McDonald's bearing was always kind and generous to a fault, and his tread and manner carried for him a remembrance of his long line of military ancestry." ==Family== McDonald married Mary Eliza McCormick (October 18, 1840 – February 8, 1934{{Harvnb|McIlhany|1903|pp=153–154.}}{{Harvnb|Couper|1952|p=13.}}), daughter of Colonel Francis McCormick and his wife Rose Mortimer Ellzey, on December 17, 1867 at her family's estate "Frankford" near [[Berryville, Virginia|Berryville]] in [[Clarke County, Virginia|Clarke County]], Virginia.{{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=229.}} Mary was born on October 18, 1840 at "Weehaw" in Clarke County and was educated at Richmond Seminary. McDonald and his wife had four children, two of whom survived to adulthood: *Mary McDonald (born and died March 1869, Lexington, Virginia) *Rose Mortimer Ellzey McDonald Skoggs (November 23, 1871, Lexington, Virginia – 1953, Berryville, Virginia) *Angus McDonald (May 28, 1873, Lexington, Virginia – January 17, 1905, [[Milner, Idaho|Milner]], [[Idaho]]){{Harvnb|Williams|1911|p=238.}} *Nannie Frank McDonald (January 17, 1883, Washington, D.C. – April 10, 1886, Washington, D.C.) ===Genealogy=== In 1890, McDonald applied for and acquired membership in [[Sons of the American Revolution|National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution]] through the organization's District of Columbia branch. He qualified for membership through his direct male-line great-grandfather, Colonel [[Angus McDonald (Virginia militiaman)|Angus McDonald]], who served in the [[French and Indian War]], [[Dunmore's War]], and the [[American Revolutionary War]] after immigrating to the [[Thirteen Colonies]] from [[Inverness]], [[Scotland]] following his banishment after the [[Battle of Culloden]]. Colonel Angus McDonald was appointed by General [[George Washington]] to serve as a [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] in command of Virginia revolutionary forces. He also served on various revolutionary committees throughout the war. McDonald also qualified for membership through his descent from his great-grandfather, William Sanford of Hampshire County, Virginia, and through his great-great-grandfather, William McGuire of [[Frederick County, Virginia|Frederick County]], Virginia, both of whom served as [[commissioned officer]]s in Virginia revolutionary forces.
